awd_titl_txt: Constraining the Degradation Pathways of Siloxanes in the Atmosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Atmospheric Chemistry Program in the Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences supports Professor Eleanor Browne and her graduate and undergraduate students. They study the atmospheric degradation processes of the organosilicon compounds known as siloxanes. Siloxanes are high-production compounds manufactured for a variety of uses, including as components of adhesives, coatings, and personal care products. The siloxanes can be detected in environmental samples worldwide including in remote Arctic regions. Due to the environmental persistence of these compounds and concerns over their toxicity to aquatic organisms, the environmental chemistry of siloxanes is an emerging area of interest. In the environment, siloxanes preferentially partition to the atmosphere where they undergo chemical reactions to form new products. These products may have a different fate than the original compound. This project improves the understanding of the timescale and products of the atmospheric degradation of siloxanes and provides the data necessary to evaluate their environmental fate. Through this project, graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students receive training in atmospheric chemistry techniques and analytical instrumentation. Students also develop scientific communication skills by creating videos describing the work. Results are incorporated into undergraduate educational materials.
  
This project uses laboratory experiments to investigate the multigenerational atmospheric chemistry of siloxanes. The reaction rates of common linear and cyclic siloxanes with the hydroxyl radical and chlorine atom are measured to understand the lifetime of the compounds. The work investigates the mechanism and products of the gas-phase oxidation of siloxanes under conditions approximating urban, rural, and remote atmospheres. Experiments probing the uptake of oxidation products into particles explore the interactions between gas-phase siloxanes and submicron particles. Both reactants and products are measured in real time with chemical ionization mass spectrometry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Siloxanes are high production chemicals that preferentially partition to the atmosphere. Although historically considered environmentally safe, new research and policy decisions suggest emerging areas of concern. Siloxanes  preferentially partition to the atmosphere and thus understanding their atmospheric chemistry is critical for understanding the ultimate environmental impact of these molecules. The work here used a combination of laboratory experimental investigations and theory to improve our understanding of siloxane atmospheric chemistry. 

Specific outcomes with respect to intellectual merit include the development of a new measurement technique to probe the composition of siloxane oxidation products, measurements of the rate constants for oxidation of siloxanes by the hydroxyl radical and chlorine atom, and the first measurement of the oxidation products under conditions that reflect remote, rural, and urban atmospheres. Based on these outcomes we were able to conclude that oxidation by chlorine atom is likely a minor degradation pathway on a global scale but is locally important in urban environments which is where the majority of siloxane emissions occur. The siloxane oxidation products differed significantly from expectations based on traditional gas-phase reactions. We identified new reaction pathways that explain our results as well as areas that require future investigation. Importantly, our results suggest that for the siloxanes expected to be most prevalent in the environment, octamethylcyclotetrasiloxane and decamethylcyclopentasiloxane, the major oxidation product remains constant regardless of if the reaction occurs in a remote, rural, or urban atmosphere - a surprising result. This greatly simplifies how the chemistry can be represented in models used to investigate the environmental impacts of these molecules. Finally, our work suggests that the siloxane oxidation products are likely to have long atmospheric lifetimes and as such, understanding the environmental impact of these molecules requires monitoring not just siloxanes, but their oxidation products as well. Currently, siloxane oxidation products are not routinely measured, thus negatively impacting our understanding of the environmental fate of these molecules. 

Specific outcomes with respect to broader impacts include the incorporation of scientific results from the work into undergraduate chemistry courses, workforce development of a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students, broad dissemination of the results of our work, and improved knowledge of siloxane environmental chemistry that can be used for evaluating and developing relevant policies.
